sub_topic: Prove that the Cartesian product of two sets is distributive over union.
message_1: Let A = {1, 2} and B = {3, 4}. Using the definition of the Cartesian product and the distributivity of union, prove that (A x B) ∪ (A x C) = A x (B ∪ C) for any set C.
message_2:
To prove that (A x B) ∪ (A x C) = A x (B ∪ C) for any set C, we will first define the Cartesian product and the distributivity of union.

The Cartesian product of two sets A and B, denoted as A x B, is the set of all ordered pairs (a, b) where a ∈ A and b ∈ B. In other words, A x B = {(a, b) | a ∈ A, b ∈ B}.

The distributivity of union states that for any sets A, B, and C, A ∪ (B ∪ C) = (A ∪ B) ∪ (A ∪ C).

Now, let's prove that (A x B) ∪ (A x C) = A x (B ∪ C) for any set C.

1. (A x B) ∪ (A x C) = {(a, b) | a ∈ A, b ∈ B} ∪ {(a, c) | a ∈ A, c ∈ C}
2. = {(a, x) | a ∈ A, x ∈ B ∪ C} (by definition of union)
3. = A x (B ∪ C) (by definition of Cartesian product)

Thus, we have shown that (A x B) ∪ (A x C) = A x (B ∪ C) for any set C.
